choices.text: FFA would show dye leakage on the disc and from inferior temporal vessels
Patient's blood pressure and lipid levels need to be normalised
Loss of pericyte is the first histopathological finding in this condition
Patient would need to undergo Nd:YAG laser retinal photocoagulation

questions.text: This 55-year old patient had a distant vision of 6/6p, with glasses, in both eyes. He is on Telmesartan 40mg/day and on Metformin 1g/day. His borderline cholesterol levels are managed by lifestyle adjustments. His HbA1 is 7.5. He came for an annual fundus examination. Which of the following is true about this patient whose fundus image is shown here?
questions.solution:
This fundus image shows features of NPDR – severe stage.

Management of any stage of Diabetic retinopathy would need management of glucose levels and the systemic factors like BP, lipids, urea/creatinine.

Fundus Image does not show neovascularisation. Hence, proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is ruled out. So, option A is ruled out. Leakage of dye from new vessels occurs in PDR, on FFA.

Thickening of the retinal capillary basement membrane is the first histopathological finding in diabetic retinopathy.

Severe NPDR may need a PRP(Pan Retinal Photocoagulation), especially if the patient is less likely ot followup regularly. Laser used for PRP is double-frequency Nd:YAG laser(532nm) whos principle is photocoagulation and not Nd:YAG laser(1064nm) whose principle is photodisruption.

choices.text: it is due to breakdown of inner blood-retinal-barrier
It is located in the inner plexiform layer
It stains with fluorescein on angiography

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the retinal finding marked in the image?
questions.solution:
Cotton-wool spots(also known as soft exudates) are retinal nerve fibre layer infarcts. They appear as localized, white-yellowish, fluffy patches with feathery borders

It is a sign of retinal ischemia. It develops secondary to obstruction of a retinal arteriole with resultant ischemia. The focal hypoxia causes blockage of axoplasmic transport leading to axoplasmic accumulation within the nerve fiber layer

They rarely cause vision loss unless they involve the fovea

They typically resolve within 6–12 weeks.

In patients who have a cotton-wool spot and no known history of diabetes, an elevated blood sugar level is identified in 20% of patients and an elevated blood pressure (diastolic blood pressure of 90 mmHg or greater) in 50% of patients.

choices.text: IAC regimen includes Melphalan, Topotecan and Carboplatin
IAC regimen includes Vincristine, Etoposide and Carboplatin
IAC is administered through the central retinal artery
Ophthalmic artery is cannulated via the Internal carotid artery in the neck for IAC

questions.text: The fundus image shows an intraocular retinoblastoma in the left eye of a 3 year old child. It was decided to proceed with intra-arterial chemotherapy. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Intra-Arterial Chemotherapy (IAC) regimen includes Melphalan, Topotecan and Carboplatin

Melphalan may be administered as a single agent in IAC for unilateral RB groups B and C tumors

IAC is a preferred modality for unilateral, multifocal RB 

IAC is administered by cannulating the Ophthalmic artery. The cannulation proceeds from the femoral vein in the groin.

VEC regimen(Vincristine, Etoposide and Carboplatin) is administered intravenously

choices.text: The given investigation is that of dark adaptometry
The observed results occur in retinitis pigmentosa
This condition is due to mutation in gene coding for calcium-sensitive chloride channel

questions.text: A 30-year old female patient came to the OPD to get an eye examination as her mother had lost useful vision due to some eye disease.Fundus exam showed no gross abnormality. ERG was normal. Subsequently another test was performed whose results are shown below.Interpret the image given below and choose the correct option:
questions.solution:
• The investigation is electro-oculography(EOG) showing decreased Arden’s ratio. (1.43 and 1.35 in the right and left eyes respectively)
  • Arden’s ratio is the ratio of the light peak and the dark trough. Value less than 1.5 is abnormal.
  • Best’s disease(Vitelliform Macular Dystrophy) is characterised by normal ERG and abnormal EOG.
  • It is due to mutation of Bestrophin gene(or VMD2 gene) that codes for a calcium-sensitive chloride channel in the RPE and is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion.
  • Best’s disease progresses through four recognized stages:
  • Stage I is previtelliform stage
  • Stage II is the vitelliform stage, characterized by the early egg yolk (typically one half to one disc diameter in size) and, later, scrambled egg appearances. Patients may retain good visual acuity until the scrambled egg stage.
  • Stage III presents layering of the fluid subretinal material, called a pseudohypopyon
  • Stage IV corresponds to greater hyperpigmentation, possible neovascularization and fibrous scarring in the atrophic stage

questions.text: This is the Amsler grid of a patient's left eye who came with complaints of painless decreased vision. All of the following may be possible causes except:
questions.solution:
Amsler’s grid is a macular function test.

This Amsler’s grid shows a central scotoma and the wavy lines are indicative of metamorphopsia experienced by the patient. Metamorphopsia and central scotoma are symptoms suggestive of macular pathologies.

All the options affect the macula except sickle cell retinopathy which predominantly affects the peripheral retina

choices.text: Capillary non-perfusion areas of 10DD area or more, on OCT
b wave is absent on ERG

questions.text: Regarding ischemic CRVO, which of the following is false?
questions.solution:
Capillary non-perfusion(CNP) areas of 10DD area or more is seen in Ischemic type of CRVO. CNP areas are visualised on FFA and not OCT.

Capillary non-perfusion areas of 5DD area or more is seen in Ischemic type of BRVO.(Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion)

choices.text: It is an idiopathic inflammatory venous occlusive disease
It is characterized by three overlapping stages of vasculitis, occlusion, and retinal neovascularization.
It is essentially a clinical diagnosis
Recurrent retinal hemorrhage is the hallmark of this disease

questions.text: Identify the false statement
questions.solution:
This is a fundus image of Eale’s disease(periphlebitis retinae). It is characterised by vasculitis (type III hypersensitivity) involving the peripheral retinal veins.

Recurrent vitreous haemorrhage(not retinal emorrhage) is the hallmark of Eales’ disease

Treatment is usually corticosteroids in the inflammation stage and retinal laser photocoagulation in the proliferative stage of the disease.

choices.text: Fluid between RPE and neurosensory retina

questions.text: The above OCT image shows:
questions.solution: The OCT image shows subretinal fluid(SRF) between RPE and neurosensory retina(NSR) at the fovea; typically seen in Central serous chorioretinopathy.

questions.text: Crystalline maculapathy may be caused by:
questions.solution:
Causes of crystalline maculopathy:

  1. Tamoxifen
  2. Methoxyflurane
  3. Canthaxanthine
  4. Nitrofurantoin
  5. Cystinosis
  6. Bietti’s crystalline retinopathy

questions.text: Salmon patch on the retina is seen in:
questions.solution:
Salmon patches are seen in non-proliferative stage of sickle cell retinopathy.

Occlusion of retinal vasculature first appears in the peripheral retina as 'salmon patches', which represent retinal hemorrhage from superficial blood vessels. Although they are initially red, they become salmon -colored due to the hemolysis of red blood cells

questions.text: Regarding this bi-specific monoclonal antibody Farcicimab, Fab fragments are against:
questions.solution:
Faricimab is the first bispecific antibody for intravitreal administration that targets two key factors that contribute to diabetic retinopathy and diabetic macular edema:

  1. Vascular endothelial growth factor(VEGF-A) and
  2. Angiopoietin-2 (Ang-2)

It blocks Ang-2, which has been shown to be upregulated with increased vitreous levels in DR. Ang-2 works through the TIE-2 pathway and is potentially detrimental because it causes pericyte loss. This in turn, leads to vessels leaking and proliferation in DR.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of this instrument is used to view the posterior pole?
questions.solution:
This is a Goldmann 3-mirror gonioscope. It is an indirect gonioscope which uses mirrors to overcome total internal reflection.

The examination is performed at the slit lamp

The Goldmann three-mirror lens has one mirror dedicated to viewing the angle and two additional mirrors for examining the peripheral retina.

  1. Mirror for gonioscopy is inclined at 59º and is tongue-shaped(B in the image)
  2. Mirror to view equatorial retina is inclined at 67º and is trapezoid(C in the image)
  3. Mirror to view peripheral retina and pars planais inclined at 73º and is rectangular(D in the image)

The central +60D lens (A in the image) is used to view the posterior pole(central retina)

questions.text: Silent choroid on FFA is seen in:
questions.solution:
The hallmark of Stargardt’s disease is premature accumulation of lipofuscin (a brown-yellow autofluorescent pigment associated with aging) in RPE, causing a pattern of yellowish flecks(pisciform or fishtail-like lesions) that extend outward from the macula. Recently they are thought to represent degenerated photoreceptor cells.

The diffuse accumulation of this lipofuscin material results in the classic dark or 'silent' choroid identified on fluorescein angiography due to masking of choroidal fluorescence

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
This is a fundus fluorescein angiography image of left eye.

Microaneurysms, venous changes(beading, looping and sausaging) are findings seen in NPDR(Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy).

Enlarged FAZ(Foveal Avascular Zone) is diagnostic of Ischemic maculopathy. The current management of ischemic maculopathy is Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGFs. Macular grid laser is contraindicated in ischemic maculomathy.

questions.text: The image shows:
questions.solution:
The hallmark of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is neovascularization that occurs at the vitreoretinal interface.

Neovascularization is often associated with tractional retinal detachment and vitreous hemorrhage, which are leading causes of visual loss in patients with diabetes.

NVD(NeoVascularisation Disc) is  defined as new vessels located at the disc or within 1 disc diameter from its margin

NVE(NeoVascularisation Elsewhere) is defined as new vessels anywhere on the retina beyond this area.

Seafan neovascularisation is seen in sickle cell retinopathy. It is characteristically seen in the peripheral retina(and mid-peripheral)

choices.text: Serum assay of lysosomal enzyme arylsulfatase A (ARSA)

questions.text:
A male baby aged 1 year and 6 months, was brought by his mother by seizures, cough, and fever for about one week. He was admitted to the hospital twice before due to otitis and pneumonia. The mother gave history of 4 relatives who died before the completion of two years of life.
He was born at a gestational age of 36 weeks. When the baby was one month old, it was observed that the baby had little power for holding its head or moving its limbs. Since then, the weakness has become progressively evident. The mother noticed that the baby did not see as other children of the same age.
In the hospital initial exam the child had fever, rhonchi on chest auscultation and marasmus-like secondary protein-energy malnutrition. The neurological examination revealed psychomotor retardation, horizontal and bilateral nystagmus, muscle weakness, generalized hyperreflexia, clumsiness, and presence of Babinski and Moro signal. The ophthalmoscopic examination was very difficult due to the nystagmus, and showed a similar finding in both the eyes. Fundus image of the left eye is shown. The diagnosis is accomplished by:
questions.solution:
The pathogenesis of Tay-Sachs disease is attributable to the accumulation of GM2 trihexosylceramide secondary to defects of β hexosaminidase A enzyme, caused by mutation in the alpha subunit of the hexominidase A gene on chromosome 15q.

GM2 trihexosylceramide accumulates predominantly in retinal ganglion cells whereby retina becomes turbid with milky-white coloration. As the ganglion cells atrophy and disappear, the cherry red spot may become less prominent and blindness with optic atrophy eventually ensues.

Gangliosidosis is most plentiful in the gray matter with the most of clinical and pathologic manifestations on the nervous system. This is typically present early in the course of illness, is frequently a helpful clue in diagnosis and has been detected even in the fetal stage.

Infantile Tay-Sachs disease is  characterized by progressive loss of neurological function, hyperirritability, and progressive weakness. The infants rapidly lose motors and intellectual skills after the end of the first year and may crawl but never walk. The natural course leads to a decerebrate, vegetative state by second to fourth year of life and death.

A juvenile form of Tay-Sachs disease exists, with late onset and slower course but a similar constellation of signs.

The mildest form of the disease is the adult sub-type, also called late-onset Tay-Sachs disease (LOTS). Manifestations include ataxia, dysarthria, muscle weakness, and dementia. But, in that form, no cherry red spot is .

One final variant is the chronic form, with patients surviving well into adulthood.

The diagnosis of the GM2 gangliosidosis is accomplished by assaying for the activity of individual β hexosaminidase isoenzymes in serum or cultured cells from affected individuals

questions.text: A 37-year old patient presented with decrease in vision. His vision was 6/18 in the right eye. His fundus image and OCT are shown here. The management would involve which of the following?
questions.solution:
Cystoid macular edema(CME) is one of the causes of loss of central vision in retinitis pigmentosa. OCT shows CME

Inhibition of Carbonic anhydrase isoenzyme IV results in acidification of the subretinal space, increased chloride ion transport, with subsequent movement of water across the RPE into the choroid. Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and helps in the resorption of fluid from the retinal layers. CME of RP, particularly responds to topical CA inhibitors.

questions.text: The image shows:
questions.solution:
Black arrows show Lacquer cracks – Rupture of Bruch’s membrane

Blue arrow shows Temporal crescent

questions.text: What examination needs to be done in this patient on every follow-up?
questions.solution:
This fundus image shows CRVO- Central Retinal Vein Occlusion - 'Splashed tomato appearance'.

The complication seen in CRVO is 100-day glaucoma which is a neovascular glaucoma. To anticipate this complication and detect/treat it early, IOP needs to be measured at every visit and gonioscopy needs to be performed to look for Neovascularisation of the Angle.

questions.text: Spoke wheel maculopathy is seen in:
questions.solution:
X-linked retinoschisis (XLRS) is a genetic condition affecting boys and men. It is typically diagnosed in childhood, The main symptom is reduced vision that cannot be improved with glasses.

XLRS is caused by mutations in a gene on the X chromosome called RS1 which encodes a protein called retinoschisin.

Splitting of the retinal nerve fiber layer in the macula gives rise to the characteristic 'spoke - wheel' appearance.

questions.text: The given image shows the representation the right-sided fundus findings in a pre-term baby. This shows:
questions.solution:
This is Zone 1, stage 2 Plus ROP and is defined as Type 1 ROP.

Type 1 high risk prethreshold ROP:

Defined as:

  • Zone 1 plus with any stage(our baby)
  • zone 1 stage 3 with no plus and
  • zone 2 stage 2 or 3 plus

All eyes with type 1 prethreshold ROP are currently recommended for immediate treatment

Stage 2: Ridge

It is a line which has grown and has a volume of thickness and height. It extends above the plane of the retina. Small tufts of new vessels may be found



PLUS DISEASE:

Progressive vascular incompetence presenting as dilatation and tortuosity of vessels in four quadrants at posterior pole, iris vascular engorgement leading to pupillary rigidity and vitreous haze comprises the active and progressive status of ROP and is termed as the plus disease

questions.text: Where is this implant located?
questions.solution:
This is Iluvien implant containing Fluocinolone acetonide(FAc).

The 0.19-mg FAc implant (Iluvien) is an FDA-approved treatment for Diabetic Macular Edema(DME).

It is a non-biodegradable implant that continuously releases a microdose of FAc into the vitreous cavity for up to 3 years.

It is effective in chronic DME with the added value of decreasing the treatment burden of multiple intravitreal injections.

Fluocinolone acetonide is a synthetic fluorinated glucocorticoid. It has selective and potent agonist properties by binding to the cytosolic glucocorticoid receptor with high affinity; it is devoid of mineralocorticoid activity.

Two extended-release (i.e., lasting up to 3 years) drug delivery systems containing fluocinolone acetonide (FAc) have been approved by the FDA for intravitreal use: Retisert and Iluvien

  1. Retisert contains 0.59 mg of FAc, which is approved for the treatment of chronic non-infectious posterior segment uveitis.
  2. Iluvien contains a dose of 0.19 mg of FAc and is approved for the treatment of diabetic macular edema

questions.text: All of the retinal cells use glutamate as neurotransmitter except:
questions.solution:
All the neurons in the vertical pathway(photoreceptors, bipolar cells and ganglion cells) use glutamate as neurotransmitter.

Amacrine cell is an inhibitory neuron and uses glycine and GABA. Starburst amacrine cells use Acetyl choline. Dopaminergic Amacrine cells use Dopamine.

choices.text: This condition is characterised by a ring of parafoveal RPE depigmentation that spares a foveal island
This can progress even after the drug is stopped
SD-OCT would show a localized thinning of the photoreceptor layers in the parafoveal region
mFERG is the primary screening test for her condition

questions.text: A 55-year old female patient being treated for SLE presents to eye OPD with complaints of bilateral decrease in vision. She has no other comorbidities. Fundus was examined and the FAF images of both the eyes are shown below. Identify the false statement regarding her condition:
questions.solution:
This is a patient with Hydroxychloroquine toxicity.

Recommended dose of HCQ: Maximum daily HCQ use of <5.0 mg/kg real weight, which correlates better with risk than ideal weight.

Risk of Toxicity: The risk of toxicity is dependent on daily dose and duration of use. At recommended doses, the risk of toxicity up to 5 years is under 1% and up to 10 years is under 2%, but it rises to almost 20% after 20 years. However, even after 20 years, a patient without toxicity has only a 4% risk of converting in the subsequent year.

The primary screening tests are:

Automated visual fields plus spectral-domain optical coherence tomography(SD OCT)

SD OCT shows localized thinning of the photoreceptor layers in the parafoveal region. These localized areas of photoreceptor loss are strong indicators of toxicity. Initial damage sometimes can be recognized as distinct focal interruption of the photoreceptor outer segment structural lines

MfERG, Fundus Autofluorescence(FAF) imaging are additional screening tests that may be done when available or as needed.

FAF  reveals:

  • Early parafoveal or extramacular photoreceptor damage as an area of increased autofluorescence(seen in the image) that may precede thinning on SD OCT.
  • Late RPE loss appears as a dark area of reduced autofluorescence

RISK FACTORS for HCQ toxicity:


Lesser risk factors:

  • Age
  • Liver disease
  • Genetics – ABCA4 pOlymorphisms

questions.text: second order neurons are situated in which of the retinal layers?
questions.solution:
• First order neuron – Photoreceptors
  • Second order neuron – Bipolar cells
  • Third order neuron – Ganglion cells
  • Fourth order neuron – Lateral Geniculate Body

In the image of retinal layers:

  1. Ganglion cell layer
  2. Inner nuclear layer(containing cell bodies of bipolar cells, horizontal cells, amacrine cells and Muller cells)
  3. Outer nuclear layer(containing cell bodies of photoreceptors)
  4. Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE)

questions.text: All of the following are complications of this procedure except:
questions.solution:
Pan-Retinal Photocoagulation(PRP) results in increased dark adaptation time(delayed dark adaptation) as the rods, present in the mid-peripheral retina, are destroyed.

Choroidal NeoVascular Membrane(CNVM) occurs if high energy laser burns are applied.

questions.text: Inner blood retinal barrier is formed by:
questions.solution:
Inner blood retinal barrier is formed by tight junctions between the endothelial cells of retinal capillaries. Contributions come from pericytes and  Muller cells also.

Outer blood retinal barrier is formed by tight junctions between the RPE cells

questions.text: Shifting fluid is seen in:
questions.solution:
Shifting fluid is the hallmark of serous/exudative retinal detachment

Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment typically presents with sudden painless decrease in vision, flashes of light(photopsia) and floaters

questions.text: A 60-year old diabetic patient underwent cataract surgery in his left eye and his post-op visual recovery was poor. On examination, he was found to have significant macular edema, CDR was 0.7. Goldmann applanation tonometry showed 30mmHg and his pachymetry was 600microns. Which of the following drugs is best avoided?
questions.solution: This patient has glaucoma as well as macular edema. Latanoprost has to be avoided as it precipitates/aggravates macular edema. Timolol is only a relative contraindication in diabetic patients.

questions.text: What surgery is being performed?
questions.solution: Scleral buckling (SB), is still being successfully employed for the repair of primary uncomplicated RD although primary pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) has been increasingly used in the management of rhegmatogenous RD
